Optimal Privacy Preserving for Federated Learning in Mobile Edge Computing

Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) with quantization and deliberately added noise over wireless networks is a promising approach to preserve user differential privacy while reducing wireless resources. Specifically, an FL learning process can be fused with quantized Binomial mechanism-based updates contributed by multiple users to reduce the communication overhead/cost and to protect the privacy of participating users. However, optimizing quantization parameters, communication resources (e.g., transmit power, bandwidth, and quantization bits), and the added noise to guarantee the differential privacy requirement and performance of the learned FL model remains an open and challenging problem. This article aims to jointly optimize the level of quantization, parameters of the Binomial mechanism, and communication resources so as to maximize the convergence rate under the constraints of the wireless network and differential privacy (DP) requirement. To that end, we first derive a novel DP budget estimation of the FL with quantization and Binomial noise that is tighter than the state-of-the-art bound. We then analyze the relationship between the convergence rate and the transmit power, the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the quantization/noise parameters and provide a theoretical bound on the convergence rate. This theoretical bound is decomposed into two components, including the variance of the global gradient and an upper bound on the quadratic bias that can be minimized by optimizing the communication resources, quantization, and added noise parameters. The resulting optimization turns out to be a Mixed-Integer Non-linear Programming (MINLP) problem. To tackle it, we first transform this MINLP problem into a new problem whose solutions are proved to be the optimal solutions of the original one. We then propose an approximate algorithm to solve the transformed problem with an arbitrary relative error guarantee. Extensive simulations show that under the same wireless resource constraints and differential privacy protection requirements, the proposed approximate algorithm achieves an accuracy close to the accuracy of the conventional FL without quantization and no added noise. The results can achieve a higher convergence rate while preserving usersâ€™ privacy.

Index Terms:
Binomial mechanism, differential privacy, federated learning, quantization, communication resources, convergence rate, approximate algorithm, wireless.

I Introduction

The rapid growth of mobile devices and services resulted in a huge amount of data for artificial intelligence (AI) based mobile applications, e.g., healthcare and e-commerce services. However, constructing a global model from big data is still challenging. First, due to privacy concerns, mobile users are not always willing to share their raw data (e.g., location, information, and travel habits/data). Second, fusing usersâ€™ data at a server may incur significant communication overhead/cost. In this context, Federated Learning (FL), among various distributed learning frameworks, has recently emerged as a potential solution to address these two challenges. Specifically, instead of requiring mobile users to share their raw data, FL only requires users to send their gradients based on their local data to a centralized server for the learning process. By doing so, not only the communication cost significantly decreases but also usersâ€™ privacy concerns are alleviated [2].

However, FL faces different challenges when deployed over wireless networks [3]. First, although only local gradients from mobile users are sent to the server, the communication cost remains a major concern for the FL over wireless networks (FLoWNs). The reason is that a mobile AI-based application may require updates/data from a large number of devices (in the order of thousands or more), thus putting significant stress on network resources [4]. Additionally, to achieve a certain accuracy level, multiple rounds of information exchange between the participating devices and the aggregating server are required. These problems are particularly more pronounced with complex deep learning models in which a local update may contain millions of parameters [5]. Second, due to its broadcast/open nature, wireless networks are vulnerable to many types of attacks, such as Man-in-the-Middle, DDoS, and Sybil, leading to privacy concerns [6]. Recent studies (e.g., [7], [8], and [9]) revealed that it is possible to retrieve the original data from the victimsâ€™ shared local gradients. This can void the privacy protection advantage of FL.

To address the above challenges, a few works have adopted a quantization technique to reduce communication costs. For example, in [10] and [11], the gradient elements are rounded to either 1 or -1. The authors in [12] presented another quantized FL framework that periodically averages the modelâ€™s parameters at the serverâ€™s side and quantizes the message-passing from edge nodes to the server. Furthermore, to improve the performance of FL (e.g., convergence rate), each node updates its local model by applying stochastic gradient descent (SGD) after a fixed number of iterations. Finally, to better scale the system, the server only updates the model with a fraction of the total nodes in each round. Similarly, the study in [13] proposed an FL with quantization constraint on the gradients. To establish a theoretical guarantee, the authors showed that the error caused by the quantization scheme is bounded by a term that decreases exponentially with the number of users. In [14], the authors proposed algorithms with periodic quantization and analyzed their convergence properties. In particular, they derived an upper bound on the learning time of various objective functions, including strongly convex and non-convex ones. In [15], the authors proposed a heterogeneous quantization approach that allows users to adapt the quantization parameters according to their communication resources. The network was partitioned into groups, and the local model user updates were divided into segments and aggregated the updates on segments. The authors demonstrated that their framework guarantees secure aggregation simultaneously in Byzantine scenarios and achieves convergence in non-Byzantine scenarios. Unlike the above works, the authors in [16] proposed a strategy to adjust the quantization levels during the training process. Through simulations on deep neural networks, they showed that their method achieves fewer communicated bits compared to a fixed quantization level policy. Interested readers are referred to [17] for a comprehensive survey on model quantization for deep neural networks.

To address privacy concerns in FL, there is a rising interest in Differential Privacy (DP), which is a scheme to share group pattern information of a dataset while securing the privacy of individuals. It uses a privacy budget parameter to measure the distinguishing probability between two datasets that differ by one individual record. The idea of DP is to add noise to private records in the dataset before aggregation. In [18], the authors proved that by adjusting the artificial noise, any privacy protection level can be satisfied. They also analyzed the optimal number of devices to maximize the convergence rate of the underlying learning process. This theoretical analysis also captures the trade-off between the privacy level and the convergence rate as well as the impact of the number of devices. To preserve user privacy and reduce the communication cost, the authors in [19] integrated FL with two-bit quantization and local DP mechanisms over an Internet of Vehicles network. The local DP mechanisms include a three-output mechanism for a small privacy budget, an optimal piecewise mechanism (PM-OPT), a suboptimal mechanism (PM-SUB), and a hybrid combining of PM-OPT and PM-SUB mechanism for a large privacy budget. In [20], the authors considered a Gaussian mechanism for adding noise to the gradients of FL. Compared to other works, this work achieves a tighter bound on the privacy budget. The authors in [21] studied the communication efficiency, privacy, and convergence trade-offs between the federated communication cost and local DP SDG algorithm. In particular, the proposed algorithm applied for the empirical risk minimization (ERM) optimization problem while guaranteeing the communication efficiency and privacy restrictions applied for the FL network. The authors leveraged the advantages of client subsampling and data subsampling as well as the shuffled model of privacy to deal with the limitation of DP. Theoretically, the proposed algorithm provides a lower bound on the ERM problem. Readers are referred to [22] for a more comprehensive survey of DP in FL.

Note that all aforementioned works do not take into account optimization of the system parameters (e.g., transmit power, bandwidth, and transmission time) and the quantization/noise factors while guaranteeing the DP of users in the underlying FL process. This problem is, in fact, very challenging since privacy-preserving methods often add noise to data or use quantization, hence significantly reducing the learning quality. For example, the authors in [2] proposed a framework that leverages quantization and Binomial mechanisms to reduce communication costs and provide DP. However, they only focused on the theoretical side and did not study the inherent factors of an FL system over wireless networks, e.g., limited bandwidth, transmit power, and transmission time. Moreover, the optimization of wireless/communication resources is often done on a short-term basis (e.g., at a packet of a frame length) while the learning convergence rate/accuracy must be optimized over a much longer time scale. Studying the impact of these system parameters on the performance of FLoWNs with regard to DP protection, learning accuracy, and convergence rate is the focus of this article. Our major contributions are as follows:

  • â€¢

    Derive a novel differential privacy budget estimation of the FL with quantization and Binomial noise. This tighter privacy budget estimation allows us to study the convergence rate optimization problem over a larger feasible region, hence achieving a higher convergence rate compared to ones that use the known privacy budget estimation [2]. This is inline with the idea recently reported in [23] where the privacy budget can be treated as a type of resource.

  • â€¢

    Analyze the relationship between the convergence rate and the transmit power, the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the quantization/noise parameters and provide a theoretical bound on the convergence rate. Later, it can be seen that the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the transmit power only appear on the right-hand side of a constraint which is a function that monotonically increases with respect to these parameters. Thus, we can fix two among three parameters, i.e., the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the transmit power, to optimize the other parameter.

  • â€¢

    Decompose the bound into two components, including the variance of the global gradient and the quadratic bias introduced by the quantization/noise mechanism, that can be minimized by optimizing the transmit power, quantization, and noise-added parameters. The resulting optimization turns out to be a Mixed-Integer Non-linear Programming (MINLP) problem. To tackle it, we transform this MINLP problem into a new problem whose solutions are proved to be the optimal solutions of the original one. We then design an approximate algorithm that can solve the transformed problem with an arbitrary relative error guarantee.

  • â€¢

    Extensive simulations show that for the same resources, the proposed approach achieves an accuracy close to that of the conventional FL without quantization and no noise added. This suggests a faster convergence rate for the proposed wireless FL framework while optimally preserving usersâ€™ privacy.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II presents the architecture of FL with added noise and quantized gradients over Mobile Edge Computing (MEC), the theoretical analysis of the privacy budget estimation, and the bound on the convergence rate. The problem formulation, its approximate algorithm, and the complexity analysis are in Section III. The experiments and discussion of the numerical results are in Section IV. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section V.

II System Model and convergence analysis

This work considers a MEC architecture in which a Mobile Edge Server (MES) orchestrates an FL process consisting of Mğ‘€M mobile devices [24]. Each mobile device kğ‘˜k, kâˆˆ{1,â€¦,M}ğ‘˜1â€¦ğ‘€k\in\{1,\ldots,M\}, has a private local dataset. This dataset can be created through the userâ€™s activities captured by this device (e.g., health- or travel-related data) and hence subject to data privacy protection.

II-B Quantization and Privacy for FL over MEC

As mentioned before, to deal with data-intensive local gradients (millions of data points, as in [27]) that significantly consume the resources of mobile devices and the MES, quantization is often employed [2, 12]. Therefore, we adopt a stochastic qğ‘q-level quantization which converts the real values of the gradients into integer values with log2â¡(q)subscript2ğ‘\log_{2}(q) bits [28], thus significantly reducing the communication overhead. This quantization mechanism is parameterized by the maximum value of the gradient Dğ·D and the quantization level qğ‘q.

At the beginning of the training process, the server instructs the devices of the quantization parameters Dğ·D and qğ‘q. A simple choice of Dğ·D is the maximum value of the loss function gradient [2]. Specifically, similar to [2], we define Vâ€‹(j)ğ‘‰ğ‘—V(j) of an integer jâˆˆ[0,qâˆ’1]ğ‘—0ğ‘1j\in[0,q-1] as follows:

Thereby, the gradient size is significantly reduced by controlling the parameters, i.e., the quantization level qğ‘q and the maximum value of the gradient Dğ·D. It is worth noting that here we assume homogeneous users/devices where the same quantization parameters are applied to gradients of all users and all rounds. In practice, one can also use adaptive gradient quantization [29] to leverage the heterogeneity of users/devices or even the change in each updating round/iteration.

Another major challenge when employing an FL system over MEC is the leak of usersâ€™ privacy while devices share their local gradients. A potential solution to guarantee the DP for mobile devices is to add random noise to the local gradient updates [30]. As defined in [30], a randomized mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M} satisfies (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy if for two neighboring input datasets, say xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y, differ by up to one element, and for any output set ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} of â„³â„³\mathcal{M} we have:

In our work, we adopt the Binomial mechanism [2] to achieve the (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy.

The rationale behind Eq. (4) is that the variance of the Binomial mechanism nâ€‹pâ€‹(1âˆ’p)ğ‘›ğ‘1ğ‘np(1-p) needs to exceed a lower bound to guarantee the (Ïµ,Î´italic-Ïµğ›¿\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy requirement. This lower bound is directly proportional to the number of dimensions dğ‘‘d and inversely proportional to the probability of privacy broken.

The authors in [2] showed that the right-hand side of Eq. (5) is a privacy budget estimation when the condition (4) holds. Here, we derive a tighter privacy budget estimation in Theorem 1 below. Intuitively, for the same value of (q,n,p,Pk)ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜(q,n,p,P_{k}), the privacy budget estimation in (12) is smaller than the privacy budget estimation in (5) (more details are presented in Appendix A). Therefore, given a privacy budget upper bound ÏµÂ¯Â¯italic-Ïµ\bar{\epsilon}, the proposed privacy budget estimation allows us to study the convergence rate optimization problem over a larger feasible region, compared to the known privacy budget estimation in [1] (hence potentially yielding a higher convergence rate). The significance of this tighter privacy budget estimation can be more pronounced where the privacy budget can be treated as a type of resource, as recently reported in [23].

Proposition 1.

Unlike the privacy budget estimation derived in [2], our privacy budget estimation in Eq. (12) satisfies the following properties that are helpful in effectively designing the approximate algorithm to maximize the convergence rate under wireless networksâ€™ resource constraints and quantization/noise constraints in Section III-B: (i) Privacy budget estimation is symmetric with respect to the Binomial mechanism probability pğ‘p; (ii) Privacy budget estimation monotonically decreases with respect to the Binomial mechanism trial number nğ‘›n; and (iii) Privacy budget estimation monotonically increases with respect to the level quantization qğ‘q.

Proof.

See Appendix B. âˆ

As later seen in Section III-B, thanks to the symmetric and monotonic properties of privacy budget estimation in Eq. (12), we design an effective algorithm to solve the proposed convergence rate optimization problem under network resource and DP constraints. First, due to the symmetric property, we only need to explore half of the domain set of pğ‘p, i.e., (0,1/2]012(0,1/2] or [1/2,1)121[1/2,1) instead of the whole interval (0,1)01(0,1). Second, the monotonicity of privacy budget estimation with respect to either nğ‘›n or qğ‘q inspires a binary search over one of these variables to solve the problem.

After the quantization and Binomial processes, instead of sending the actual gradient as in a conventional FL, each device kğ‘˜k sends its quantized and added-noise â„³â€‹(ğ kâ€‹(ğ°t))â„³subscriptğ ğ‘˜superscriptğ°ğ‘¡\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t})) to the MES. The quantization significantly reduces the size of the gradient. In particular, the reduced size of the local quantized and noise-added gradient is dâ€‹log2â¡(q+n)ğ‘‘subscript2ğ‘ğ‘›d\log_{2}(q+n) bits [2]. We assume that Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiple Access (OFDMA) is employed for the uplink between mobile devices and the MES. Without losing the generality, here we assume all devices have the same bandwidth Wğ‘ŠW and transmission time Tğ‘‡T, and the server uses a dedicated channel to broadcast global updates to all devices. It should be noted that the size of quantized and noise-added gradient must not exceed the capacity of its channel:

dâ€‹log2â¡(q+n)â‰¤Rkâ€‹T,Â â€‹kâˆˆğ’¦,formulae-sequenceğ‘‘subscript2ğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜ğ‘‡Â ğ‘˜ğ’¦d\log_{2}(q+n)\leq R_{k}T,\mbox{ }k\in\mathcal{K}, (15)

where Rksubscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜R_{k} is the transmission rate of device kğ‘˜k given by Shannonâ€™s equation

Rk=Wâ€‹log2â¡(1+Pkâ€‹hkÏ‰0),Â â€‹kâˆˆğ’¦,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜ğ‘Šsubscript21subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğœ”0Â ğ‘˜ğ’¦R_{k}=W\log_{2}\bigg{(}1+\frac{P_{k}h_{k}}{\omega_{0}}\bigg{)},\mbox{ }k\in\mathcal{K}, (16)

where Ï‰0subscriptğœ”0\omega_{0}, hksubscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{k}, and Pksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k} are the noise power, the channel gain, and the transmit power of device kğ‘˜k, respectively. Thus (15) can be re-expressed as

dâ€‹log2â¡(q+n)â‰¤Wâ€‹Tâ€‹log2â¡(1+Pkâ€‹hkÏ‰0),Â â€‹kâˆˆğ’¦.formulae-sequenceğ‘‘subscript2ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘Šğ‘‡subscript21subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğœ”0Â ğ‘˜ğ’¦d\log_{2}(q+n)\leq WT\log_{2}\bigg{(}1+\frac{P_{k}h_{k}}{\omega_{0}}\bigg{)},\mbox{ }k\in\mathcal{K}. (17)

Later, we can see that the wireless resource parameters, including the transmit power, the bandwidth, and the transmission time, only appear on the right-hand side of constraint (17). In addition, the right-hand-side function of (17) monotonically increases with respect to these three resource parameters. Hence, we can optimize one of these parameters while fixing the other two parameters at the maximum allowed values to optimize the convergence rate. In particular, here we vary the transmit power Pkâˆˆ[Pkmin,Pkmax]subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k}\in[P_{k}^{\min},P_{k}^{\max}] and fix the bandwidth and transmission time at Wğ‘ŠW and Tğ‘‡T, where Wğ‘ŠW and Tğ‘‡T are the maximum bandwidth and transmission time, respectively.

Finally, the server aggregates the received quantized and randomized gradients in a similar way to the conventional SGD:

ğ ~â€‹(ğ°t)=1Kâ€‹âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦â„³â€‹(ğ kâ€‹(ğ°t)).~ğ superscriptğ°ğ‘¡1ğ¾subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦â„³subscriptğ ğ‘˜superscriptğ°ğ‘¡\tilde{\mathbf{g}}(\mathbf{w}^{t})=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\mathcal{M}\left(\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t})\right). (18)

The learning process continues until it converges. In the next section, we present a convergence analysis of our proposed SLQBM-FL.

II-C Convergence Rate Analysis of SLQBM-FL

However, the convergence rate under the estimation of the global gradient at the server is still unknown. III Problem formulation and solutions

As analyzed in the previous section, to maximize the convergence rate of SLQBM-FL under the constraints on the network resources and (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy protection, we can minimize the upper bound on BğµB in Eq. Finally, we discuss the relationship between the system parameters, e.g., the maximum transmit power, the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the optimal objective value of (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}). Remark 1 summarizes the relationship between the optimal objective value of (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}) and these parameters.

Remark 1 (Dependence of Optimal Solution Value on the System Parameters).

If the maximum transmit power Pkmaxsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k}^{\max} or the maximum transmission time Tğ‘‡T or the bandwidth Wğ‘ŠW increases, the optimal objective function of (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}) will not increase.

III-A Problem Transformation

The proposed problem (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}) is an MINLP problem. In this section, we transform (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}) to a new problem (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}) whose optimal solution set can be used to derive the optimal solution set of (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}). The advantage of (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}) over (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}) is that it can be effectively solved by approximate solutions with arbitrarily small errors. Specifically, applying transformations on the constraints of (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}), we obtain a new MINLP problem denoted as (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}).

The constraint (34) follows from the fact that the smaller the transmit power is, the better the power efficiency can be achieved. Theorem 4 formally states the relationship between the problem (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}) and the problem (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}).

Theorem 4 shows that we can obtain the solution of (Î¦1)subscriptÎ¦1(\Phi_{1}) by solving (Î¦2)subscriptÎ¦2(\Phi_{2}). An advantage of (Î¦2)subscriptÎ¦2(\Phi_{2}) in comparison with (Î¦1)subscriptÎ¦1(\Phi_{1}) is that we only need to consider the variables pğ‘p and qğ‘q, and easily derive the values of Pksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k} and nğ‘›n based on the Eqs. (33) and (34). In the next section, we propose an approximate algorithm to solve (Î¦2)subscriptÎ¦2(\Phi_{2}) that guarantees arbitrary small errors and works effectively in practice.

III-D Complexity of Algorithm 2

In Algorithm 1, we implement a binary search with respect to the Binomial mechanism parameter nğ‘›n. Therefore, the complexity of Algorithm 1 is ğ’ªâ€‹(log2â¡|ğ’©|)ğ’ªsubscript2ğ’©\mathcal{O}(\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|), where ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N} is the domain set of nğ‘›n. In practice, we assign ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N} to the set of all integers between 2 and 2bsuperscript2ğ‘2^{b}, where bğ‘b is the maximum number of bits of each gradient element, e.g., 8 or 16 [2]. In such context, the complexity of Algorithm 1 is ğ’ªâ€‹(b)ğ’ªğ‘\mathcal{O}(b).

Considering Algorithm 2, the FOR loop (lines 2-11) repeats for |ğ’¬|â€‹|ğ’«|ğ’¬ğ’«|\mathcal{Q}||\mathcal{P}| times. Inside this loop, the most significant computation is the binary search (line 3) whose complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(log2â¡|ğ’©|)ğ’ªsubscript2ğ’©\mathcal{O}(\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|). Therefore, the complexity of Algorithm 2 is ğ’ªâ€‹(|ğ’¬|â€‹|ğ’«|â€‹log2â¡|ğ’©|)ğ’ªğ’¬ğ’«subscript2ğ’©\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{Q}||\mathcal{P}|\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|). Since |ğ’«|=ğ’«Î»âˆª{1/2}â‰¤1/(2â€‹Î»)+1ğ’«subscriptğ’«ğœ†1212ğœ†1|\mathcal{P}|=\mathcal{P}_{\lambda}\cup\{1/2\}\leq 1/(2\lambda)+1, the complexity of Algorithm 2 is ğ’ªâ€‹(|ğ’¬|â€‹log2â¡|ğ’©|/Î»)ğ’ªğ’¬subscript2ğ’©ğœ†\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{Q}|\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|/\lambda), which is pseudo-polynomial. Recall that to satisfy the ÏğœŒ\rho-relative error the following condition holds: Î»<Ï/Î¼ğœ†ğœŒğœ‡\lambda<\rho/\mu. Since Î¼ğœ‡\mu is a constant, to achieve ÏğœŒ\rho-relative error, the complexity of Algorithm 2 is ğ’ªâ€‹(|ğ’¬|â€‹log2â¡|ğ’©|/Ï)ğ’ªğ’¬subscript2ğ’©ğœŒ\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{Q}|\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|/\rho).

IV Experiment results

IV-A Parameters Settings

To perform the experiments, we consider a network with 1 million mobile devices, i.e., M=106ğ‘€superscript106M=10^{6}, and in general, set the number of selected mobile devices to update the global gradient K=1000ğ¾1000K=1000. In a special case that studies the impact of the number of selected devices Kğ¾K on the convergence rate, we vary the value of Kğ¾K between 101010, 102superscript10210^{2}, 103superscript10310^{3}, and 104superscript10410^{4}. We set the square of channel gains hk2superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘˜2h_{k}^{2} following the exponential distribution with the mean g0â€‹(D0/Dk)4subscriptğ‘”0superscriptsubscriptğ·0subscriptğ·ğ‘˜4g_{0}(D_{0}/D_{k})^{4}, where g0=âˆ’40subscriptğ‘”040g_{0}=-40 dB, the reference distance D0=1subscriptğ·01D_{0}=1 m, and distance Dksubscriptğ·ğ‘˜D_{k} between the mobile edge server and device kğ‘˜k is randomly sampled from [Dmin,Dmax]subscriptğ·subscriptğ·[D_{\min},D_{\max}] with Dmin=2subscriptğ·2D_{\min}=2 m and Dmax=200subscriptğ·200D_{\max}=200 [33]. For each device, the bandwidth is set to 900 MHz [34]. The transmit power is restricted as Pkâˆˆ{1,â€¦,20}subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜1â€¦20P_{k}\in\{1,\ldots,20\} dBm, for kâˆˆ{1,â€¦,M}ğ‘˜1â€¦ğ‘€k\in\{1,\ldots,M\}, similar to [33]. We implement a three-layer neural network with 785 nodes in the input layer, 60 hidden nodes, and 10 nodes in the output layer using the ADAM training algorithm. We also use the ReLU activate function and use the infinite MNIST dataset as input, similar to [2]. The simulated framework is built with Python and NumPy. For the differential privacy security, we set Î´=10âˆ’10ğ›¿superscript1010\delta=10^{-10} [2]. In addition, we restrict the number of allowed transmit bits per parameter to 16 bits, similar to [2].

IV-B Privacy evaluation

We first aim to study the efficiency of the proposed privacy budget estimation (12) in comparison with the privacy budget estimation (5) presented in [2]. We compute the solutions (q,n,p,Pk)ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜(q,n,p,P_{k}) with respect to the privacy budget upper bound ÏµÂ¯Â¯italic-Ïµ\bar{\epsilon} which is varied from 1 to 10 using the proposed privacy budget estimation in Eq. (12). We then compute the privacy budget estimation over these solutions applying Eq. (5). The results in Fig. 2 show that our proposed privacy budget estimation gives a tighter estimation than the proposed one in [2], i.e., the right-hand side of Eq. (12) is smaller than the right-hand side of Eq. (5) with respect to the same system and quantization/noise parameters.

We then investigate the impact of the maximum privacy budget on the learning time of SLQBM-FL. Recall that the objective of (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}) is to maximize the SLQBM-FL learning rate. Thus, the lower value of (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2})â€™s objective function is, the lower the learning time of SLQBM-FL is. We study the scenarios corresponding to the privacy budget ÏµÂ¯Â¯italic-Ïµ\bar{\epsilon} varying from 1 to 10 [2]. Fig. 3 shows the objective function value Ï†â€‹(q,n,p,Pk)ğœ‘ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜\varphi(q,n,p,P_{k}) of (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}) of the solution returned by Algorithm 2 when the upper bound on differential privacy budget ÏµÂ¯Â¯italic-Ïµ\bar{\epsilon} varies from 1 to 10. It is clear that as ÏµÂ¯Â¯italic-Ïµ\bar{\epsilon} increases, i.e., the privacy requirement gets less restricted, the objective function value gets decreased, meaning that the convergence rate increases. This is stemmed from the fact that the higher the value of ÏµÂ¯Â¯italic-Ïµ\bar{\epsilon} is, the lower the amount of noise added to gradients by the Binomial mechanism is. Consequently, the learning time (indicated via our objective function) reduces due to less noise as ÏµÂ¯Â¯italic-Ïµ\bar{\epsilon} increases from 1 to 10.

IV-C Convergence rate analysis

Now, we investigate the dependence of the convergence rate on the device number Kğ¾K. Theoretically, the upper bound BğµB of the quadratic bias introduced by mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M}, which defines the objective value of both (Î¦1subscriptÎ¦1\Phi_{1}) and (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}), is inversely proportional to Kğ¾K. Therefore, the larger the value of Kğ¾K, the higher the convergence rate is. Fig. 4 shows the accuracy curves of the solutions returned by Algorithm 2 corresponding to different values of the device number K=ğ¾absentK= 101010, 102superscript10210^{2}, 103superscript10310^{3}, and 104superscript10410^{4}. It is clear that as Kğ¾K increases the convergence rate increases since the aggregated noise reduces as the number of aggregated devices increases.

We then investigate the convergence of SLQBM-FL with the parameters of quantization and Binomial mechanisms obtained by our proposed Algorithm 2, namely Prop. sol.. In this experiment, we select four baseline approaches, i.e., the conventional FL that operates without quantization and differential privacy mechanisms, and three feasible solutions to the problem (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}). In particular, the feasible solutions returned by Algorithm 2 are clustered into 3 groups based on their objective function value. We then select the solution with the smallest objective value of each group. As shown in Fig. 5, even though the quantization and Binomial mechanism introduce noise to data, our proposed solution still achieves an accuracy that is close to that of the conventional FL after 250025002500 global update rounds. We also observe that the accuracy curve of Sol. 1 gets close to the accuracy curve of our proposed solution. The reason is that the objective value of Sol. 1 is the second smallest and is close to the objective value of our proposed solution. Thus, it demonstrates the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm in optimizing the system parameters, i.e., transmit power and the quantization/noise parameters for the SLQBM-FL.

IV-D System efficiency

Next, we investigate the dependence of the objective function of (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}) on the system parameters, including the maximum transmit power Pkmaxsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k}^{\max}, the bandwidth Wğ‘ŠW, and the transmission time Tğ‘‡T, as shown in Figs. 6, 7, and 8, respectively. Generally, as these system parameters increase, the domain sets of these parameters get expanded. Thus, the objective function value of (Î¦2subscriptÎ¦2\Phi_{2}) decreases or at least does not increase. In other words, the convergence rate gets improved as increasing these communication resources.

To study the communication cost-effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, we compute the communication costs in Giga bits (Gbs) as the product of 4 integers including the number of training rounds, the number of selected mobile devices, i.e., K=1000ğ¾1000K=1000, the number of dimensions dğ‘‘d, and the number of bits per quantized gradient element. In particular, the number of training rounds counts the number of global update rounds until the accuracy achieves 88%. The reason behind the value 88% is that this value is the accuracy threshold of the most feasible solutions in empirical. The communication costs of the proposed Algorithm 2 and four baseline approaches are presented in a bar chart in Fig. 9. The result of Sol. 3 is not presented here as its accuracy cannot achieve the threshold of 88%. It is clear that the proposed algorithm solutionâ€™s communication cost is close to conventional FL and significantly lower than those of the other feasible solutions. In addition, the communication cost of the proposed algorithm is also lower than that of the FL with no quantization but with added noise, showing the effectiveness of the quantization mechanism.

Finally, we investigate the level quantization upper bound qÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{q} derived from Lemma 2. Figure 10 shows this upper bound when varying the maximum transmit power. First, it shows that as the transmit power increases, the level quantization upper bound also increases. Second, it shows the efficiency of Lemma 2 to reduce the search range of level quantization qğ‘q. In particular, when we set the number of bits per gradient element not to exceed 16 [2], instead of searching the range from 222 to 216superscript2162^{16}, we only need to consider the range from 222 to qÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{q}, which is less than 216superscript2162^{16} by a factor of 100, as shown in Fig. 10.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we first derived a tighter than the state-of-the-art differential privacy budget estimation for Federated learning over mobile edge networks with quantized gradients and added noise (to protect mobile usersâ€™ privacy). By analyzing the relationship between the convergence rate and the system parameters, i.e., the transmit power, the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the quantization/noise parameters, we provided a theoretical bound on the convergence rate. This bound was decomposed into two components, including the variance of the global gradient and the quadratic bias introduced by the quantization/noise mechanism. We then analyzed the theoretical and practical reasons to improve the convergence rate by optimizing the upper bound of the quadratic bias. We then jointly optimized the level of quantization, the Binomial mechanismâ€™s parameters, and the transmit power. The resulting problem is an MINLP. To tackle it, we transformed the problem into the new one whose optimal solutions are proved to be optimal solutions of the original one. We then designed an effective algorithm that can approximately solve the new problem with an arbitrary relative error. Extensive simulations showed with mostly the same wireless resources the proposed approach achieves an accuracy that is close to that of the conventional FL without quantization and without added noise while achieving the required DP protection. This suggested the faster convergence rate of the proposed wireless FL framework while optimally preserving usersâ€™ privacy.
